metadata.case_name: Co-operative Central Banks v. Andhra Pradesh Bank Employees Federation

facts.text: An industrial dispute arose between 25 Co-operative Central Banks in the State of Andhra Pradesh and their workmen represented by the Andhra Pradesh Bank Employees Federation, Hyderabad.
The dispute was referred by the Government of Andhra Pradesh to the Industrial Tribunal, Hyderabad, under section 10(1)(d) of the Industrial Disputes Act No. 14 of 1947.

The subject-matter of the dispute was divided into three issues: first issue comprised 17 service conditions including salary scales, dearness allowance, leave rules, etc.; second and third issues related to whether transfers of some employees of The Vijayawada Co-operative Central Bank, Ltd., Vijayawada, and The Vizianagaram Co-operative Central Bank Ltd., Vizianagaram, were justified and reliefs entitled.

Before the Industrial Tribunal, Banks raised ground that reference invalid as disputes required to be referred to Registrar under section 61 of Andhra Pradesh Co-operative Societies Act No. 7 of 1964, excluding Industrial Tribunal jurisdiction.
Tribunal treated point as preliminary issue, rejected contention of Banks as preliminary award.
Twenty-four Banks challenged preliminary decision by filing Writ Petitions Nos. 2339 and 2742 of 1968 under Art. 226 in Andhra Pradesh High Court.
High Court rejected plea of Banks, dismissing writ petitions.
Appeals to Supreme Court by certificate: Civil Appeal No. 2093/1968 by 10 Banks (petitioners in WP 2339/68), Civil Appeal No. 2094/1968 by 10 Banks (from WP 2742/68).
Conditions of service of employees laid down by special bye-laws of the Banks.

legal_issues.text: Whether the jurisdiction of the Industrial Tribunal to adjudicate on the industrial dispute referred under s.10(1)(d) of the Industrial Disputes Act was barred by s.61 of the Andhra Pradesh Co-operative Societies Act No.7 of 1964.

petitioner_arguments.text: The AP Co-operative Societies Act is a local special self-contained Act excluding other laws in conflict; s.61 has non-obstante clause requiring disputes touching constitution, management or business of society to be referred to Registrar, barring Industrial Tribunal jurisdiction.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Sections 61, 133 of AP Co-operative Societies Act; various High Court decisions

petitioner_arguments.text: Disputes between co-operative societies and employees touch the business of the societies.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.61 AP Co-op Act; High Court cases like G.I.P. Railway Employees Co-op Bank, Sagar Motor Transport, etc.

petitioner_arguments.text: Industrial Tribunal cannot alter conditions of service in bye-laws as that would be contrary to law.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Dalmia Cement, Marina Hotel, etc. (SC cases); bye-laws have force of law

petitioner_arguments.text: Issues 2 and 3 could be decided by Registrar.

respondent_arguments.text: Disputes actually referred not capable of being decided by Registrar under s.61 AP Co-op Act, so reference to Industrial Tribunal competent.

court_reasoning.text: AP Co-op Act prevails over ID Act if repugnant due to Presidential assent; jurisdiction of Tribunal barred only if disputes competently decidable by Registrar under s.61.
court_reasoning.key_observation: General proposition that s.61 bars ID Act jurisdiction if disputes covered accepted.

court_reasoning.text: Follows Deccan Merchants Co-op Bank (SC): 'business' means actual trading/commercial activity, not all affairs; disputes must be capable of resolution by Registrar.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Service conditions dispute not touching 'business'; Registrar bound by Act, rules, bye-laws (s.62(4)), cannot alter service conditions in bye-laws.

court_reasoning.text: Bye-laws not law or having force of law; like contract terms; Industrial Tribunal can vary contracts/bye-laws unlike civil court or Registrar.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Tribunal competent to grant reliefs on issue 1.

court_reasoning.text: s.16(5) irrelevant as not decision under s.61, not for workmen interests.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Registrar cannot grant relief via s.16(5) in s.61 dispute.

court_reasoning.text: No need to decide issues 2/3 as not raised in HC writs; challenge was to reference as whole.

holdings.text: Dispute on service conditions (issue 1) not covered by s.61 AP Co-op Act as not touching 'business' and not resolvable by Registrar; Industrial Tribunal has jurisdiction.

precedents_cited.case_name: Deccan Merchants Co-operative Bank Ltd. v. Dalichand Jugraj
precedents_cited.relevance: Interpretation of 'touching the business of the society' in similar s.91 Maharashtra Co-op Act applicable to s.61 AP Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: G.I.P. Railway Employees Co-operative Bank Ltd. v. Bhikhaji Merwanji Karanjia
precedents_cited.relevance: Scope of similar provision in Bombay Co-op Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sagar Motor Transport Karamachari Union v. Amar Kamgar Passenger Transport Co-operative Society
precedents_cited.relevance: Interpretation of MP Co-op Act s.55(2).

precedents_cited.case_name: S. Madhva Rao v. D.V.K. Surya Rao
precedents_cited.relevance: Full Bench on Madras Co-op Act s.51 similar to s.61.
Full Bench Bombay HC on s.54 Bombay Co-op Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: Co-operative Milk Societies Union Ltd. v. State of West Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: Dispute on wages not covered under Bengal Co-op Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: South Arcot Co-operative Motor Transport Society Ltd. v. Syed Batcha
precedents_cited.relevance: Industrial claims under ID Act, not under Co-op Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dalmia Cement Bharat Ltd. v. Their Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: Tribunal cannot exceed statutory leave limits.

precedents_cited.case_name: Management of Marina Hotel v. The Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: Similar to Dalmia on statutory prohibitions.

precedents_cited.case_name: Hindustan Times Ltd. v. Their Workmen

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Reference of industrial dispute to Tribunal.

statutes_cited.name: Andhra Pradesh Co-operative Societies Act, 1964
statutes_cited.relevance: Disputes to Registrar; overriding effect; decision per Act/rules/bye-laws.

outcome.summary: The appeals challenging the jurisdiction of the Industrial Tribunal are dismissed, upholding the High Court and Tribunal decisions that the reference under ID Act is competent and not barred by s.61 of AP Co-op Act.

key_quotes.text: "the word business has been used in a narrower sense and it means the actual trading or commercial or other similar business activity of the society"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines scope of 'business' following Deccan Merchants, excluding service conditions.

key_quotes.text: The bye-laws that are contemplated by the Act can be merely those which govern the internal management, business or administration of a society. They may be binding between the persons affected by them, but they do not have the force of a statute.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects argument that bye-laws have force of law barring Tribunal alteration.

key_quotes.text: Industrial Tribunals have the right even to vary contracts of service between the employer and the employees which jurisdiction can never be exercised by a civil court or a Registrar acting under the Co-operative Societies Act.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Affirms Tribunal's power over service conditions.
